Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bilateral BBSRC-NSF/BIO: Synthetic Biology for Lignin Utilization

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major challenges in biology is to discover ways to convert renewable plant-based material into commodity chemicals and fuels. For this process to be economically feasible, valuable products must be made from lignin, a portion of plant material that now remains mostly unused. Lignin is abundant and its chemical composition holds great potential for bioenergy production and biotechnology. This project seeks to use newly developed tools in computational and experimental biology to manipulate bacterial pathways for improved lignin degradation with the ultimate goal of developing effective methods of generating energy in a renewable fashion. A soil bacterium, Acinetobacter baylyi ADP1, that already degrades a vast array of plant derived compounds will be used in these studies. The degradation capability of this bacterium will be expanded by introducing new genes into the chromosome and by optimizing the expression of the catabolic genes for the desired applications. This integrative project will be accomplished via a multi-disciplinary collaboration, including an international component. Training opportunities will enable students to visit and conduct some of the research in the laboratories of different collaborators. All collaborators have a strong commitment to training students at the undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels. This project will be used to enhance diversity and inclusiveness in the scientific community.

Building on the conceptual framework of synthetic biology, this project will develop A. baylyi as the recipient cell (the chassis) to incorporate genetic modules (devices) to expand bacterial pathways for aromatic compound catabolism. To overcome obstacles that may arise from differences between idealized concepts and biological realities, a novel method of experimental evolution that relies on gene amplification will help optimize metabolic functions. This method exploits the exceptionally high efficiency of natural transformation and homologous recombination in A. baylyi. This bacterium is an ideal chassis for lignin biodegradation because of its powerful genetic system and ability to degrade many aromatic compounds, including those that are toxic to Escherichia coli. Experimental flux analysis and kinetic studies will be used to build dynamical models for the design, optimization, and synthetic expansion of aromatic compound catabolic abilities. Advanced computational tools, developed by a member of this research team, in collaboration with others, will also be applied: Biochemical Network Integrated Computational Explorer (BNICE). To complement these approaches, biochemical, biophysical, and structural studies will examine how the spatial orientation of enzymes can be used to improve catalytic efficiency, target metabolite flow, and prevent toxic intermediates from accumulating.

This collaborative US/UK project is supported by the US National Science Foundation and the UK Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The expansion of metabolic pathways for aromatic compound degradation in bacteria provides new avenues for biotechnology applications. For example, the lignin portion of lignocellulose is an abundant and energy dense polymer made up of aromatic subunits. Microbes can degrade lignin via slow metabolic processes that typically involve multiple organisms. Lignin could serve as an excellent renewable feedstock for producing industrial chemicals with bacteria engineered to carry out complex biochemical conversions. This approach could facilitate adoption of a bio-based economy in the future that reduces reliance on fossil fuels. Towards this goal, we sought to modify the pathways for aromatic compound catabolism in a soil bacterium, Acinetobacter baylyi ADP1. Our specific aims included demonstrating the expression and evolution of multi-step pathways for metabolizing lignin-derived aromatic compounds and improving our understanding of, and ability to alter, cellular regulation. Publications resulting from this funding demonstrate success in conferring to strain ADP1 the ability to metabolize new aromatic growth substrates. A novel laboratory method was developed and used, termed Evolution by Amplification and Synthetic biology (EASy). With this technique, foreign DNA is inserted into the bacterial chromosome. Next, a tandem array is generated of a chromosomal segment encompassing the foreign DNA.  This gene amplification step, which mimics a natural evolutionary process, can act as a rudimentary form of regulation to increase metabolic activities. After serial transfers that select cells with improved degradative capabilities, new strains emerge that have gained desired traits. To understand the mutations that confer these novel capabilities, whole genome sequencing was conducted. Mutations were identified that revealed new aspects of metabolic regulation. Continued regulatory studies are increasing understanding of fundamental biological functions and improving the ability to use bacteria to convert lignin to useful products. Strain ADP1 has an atypical genetic system that makes it an ideal host for synthetic and systems biology. This project helped with tool development to enable the scientific community to use this bacterium for a wide variety of applications.

The broader implications of this project extend beyond lignin valorization applications. The metabolism of aromatic compounds is also relevant to synthesizing and degrading plastic polymers to reduce pollution from the buildup of plastic waste in the environment. Moreover, the facile genetic system of ADP1 makes it an excellent teaching tool. This project served as the basis for teaching an undergraduate laboratory course in which students conducted authentic research projects. Research for this project was conducted by many students and scientists, including undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and senior scientists.
